title: In London Bridge, a Young Design Duo Craft an Elegant Pied-à-Terre
description: Soft palettes, an embrace of comfort, and a fluid floorplan transformed an apartment in the vibrant neighborhood
author: Valentina Raggi
excerpt: Soft palettes, an embrace of comfort, and a fluid floorplan transformed an apartment in the vibrant neighborhood
text: All products featured on Architectural Digest are independently selected by our editors. However, when you buy something through our retail links, we may earn an affiliate commission.After arriving in the United Kingdom as backpackers, Wade and Lisa, originally from Australia, made London and specifically the London Bridge neighborhood their home for a decade. Eventually the couple returned to Australia, married, but they later returned to London to buy some property in the area they had come to love.Having long been tenants in different flats in the historic neighborhood, the couple recognized an opportunity when they saw that a 1,292-square-foot Victorian home on a quiet side street was for sale. This was long before Borough Market and Renzo Piano’s Shard would make London Bridge the bustling destination that visitors flock to today.After renting the home to tenants for 20 years, the couple recently decided it was time to renovate it and use it themselves on their visits to London, which are becoming more frequent. They reached out to Duelle, an interior design firm based in London and Milan. It was founded by Micaela Nardella and Melanie Law. Nardella, who was born and raised in Milan, trained as an architect and designer, and had a decade of professional experience in Rotterdam, London, and Milan. Law, originally from Toronto, had 15 years of professional experience as an interior designer.The living room of an apartment in a Victorian building in the London Bridge neighborhood that was renovated and updated by the design duo Duelle. Vintage Sputnik-style chandelier, moss green chenille modular sofa, vintage coffee table, and floor lamp are all from M.A.H Gallery. The custom millwork around the sofa optimizes the use of space. Duelle took charge of the renovation of the London Bridge property, transforming it into a serenely contemporary pied-à-terre. “A clever and dynamic use of space was a key goal in the clients’ brief as the home lacked storage space. We also improved the circulation while enhancing the natural character of the property. Today, smart, integrated storage solutions are found throughout the flat: from the solid oak bed with storage incorporated for luggage, to custom millwork around the bed and sofa, which hides both unsightly radiators and snowboards,” the designers explain. In the kitchen, a pull-out pantry and breakfast shelving create a practical, easy-access space for food and appliances, while a multipurpose desk/island/console provides an ideal workspace for two, as well as serving as a sturdy, practical surface for unloading groceries and other items.Near the entrance to the bedroom, a vintage midcentury chest of drawers. The apartment’s aesthetic was shaped in part by the client’s love for Duelle’s joinery designs from an earlier project, the A. Gallo boutique in Assisi, Italy. “Natural oil rubbed European oak was carefully selected and used to delineate different areas within the apartment,” the designers explain. In the kitchen, they used heavier lines and shadows, adding drama and emphasis to the matte green Brazilian quartzite countertop and backsplash. “To create a feeling of spaciousness, a common palette was used throughout the apartment. Each room features a unique color for its walls and ceilings, which gives a strong impact to otherwise small spaces. Pale green tones were used in the bathroom and kitchen/living area to create a feeling of spaciousness, while the bedroom is wrapped in a rich shade of peach. Custom oak cabinets were designed for each room, with a single slab of quartzite carefully divided and used in both the kitchen and bathroom,” Nardella and Law explain.In the principal bedroom, a handcrafted solid oak storage bed by Get Laid Beds and, on the wall above the bed, two works by Ruby Bateman. Traces of the area’s past are reflected in some elements of the interior, from the basket-weave pattern of the parquet floors to the tiles in the bathroom, inspired by ancient Roman tiles found in the neighborhood that date back to the days when Londinium was a remote outpost of the empire. Much attention was paid to the choice of vintage glass lighting fixtures, a nod to the long history of glassmaking here. With their previous experience as designers of luxury hotels and private residence in London, Duelle was a natural choice for Lisa and Wade’s pied-à-terre. The result is a compact and stylish apartment with the feel of a luxury nest where everything has its defined role, all contributing to the invitingly domestic feel of the home.A glimpse of the en suite bathroom. The tub is Kaldewei and the sconce above the door is by Dyke & Dean. Foto Mariell Lind HansenThe vintage Sputnik-style chandelier, moss green chenille modular sofa, vintage coffee table, floor lamp, chairs, and footstool are all from M.A.H Gallery, as is the blanket on the sofa, Gentle Throw in off white by Atelier Vetra, from The House by M.A.H.The vintage coffee table with marble top and a modern armchair are both from M.A.H Gallery.Foto Mariell Lind HansenIn the principal bedroom, the solid oak storage bed is handcrafted by Get Laid Beds and the two paintings are by Ruby Bateman.The custom-designed desk has hidden drawers and is made of oil-treated solid European oak.A Space Age chandelier floats above a floor lamp, armchair, coffee table, and vintage floor lamp, all from M.A.H Gallery.The custom, handcrafted kitchen is paired with Art Deco wall lights, the cabinet hardware is Esor Spain, and the faucet is Lusso Stone.Foto Mariell Lind HansenIn the kitchen, a pull-out pantry and breakfast bar offer convenient, easily accessible storage for food and appliances, while a multipurpose desk/island/console provides a functional workspace for two. It also serves as a sturdy, practical surface for groceries and other items. Art Deco sconces, Esor Spain hardware, and a Lusso Stone faucet.Integrated and functional storage solutions are used throughout the flat, like this custom unit that hides the radiators.The principal bedroom, with a bed from Get Laid Beds, a midcentury sideboard, and a vintage Space Age lamp.Foto Mariell Lind HansenIn the bedroom, a custom unit hides the radiator. There’s a Space Age light fixture and, at the rear, the en suite bathroom. The floor is parquet with a basket-weave pattern that recalls the area’s past; the tiles were inspired by ancient Roman tiles that have been found in the neighborhood.
html:
All products featured on Architectural Digest are independently selected by our editors. However, when you buy something through our retail links, we may earn an affiliate commission.

After arriving in the United Kingdom as backpackers, Wade and Lisa, originally from Australia, made London and specifically the London Bridge neighborhood their home for a decade. Eventually the couple returned to Australia, married, but they later returned to London to buy some property in the area they had come to love.

Having long been tenants in different flats in the historic neighborhood, the couple recognized an opportunity when they saw that a 1,292-square-foot Victorian home on a quiet side street was for sale. This was long before Borough Market and Renzo Piano’s Shard would make London Bridge the bustling destination that visitors flock to today.

After renting the home to tenants for 20 years, the couple recently decided it was time to renovate it and use it themselves on their visits to London, which are becoming more frequent. They reached out to Duelle, an interior design firm based in London and Milan. It was founded by Micaela Nardella and Melanie Law. Nardella, who was born and raised in Milan, trained as an architect and designer, and had a decade of professional experience in Rotterdam, London, and Milan. Law, originally from Toronto, had 15 years of professional experience as an interior designer.

Duelle took charge of the renovation of the London Bridge property, transforming it into a serenely contemporary pied-à-terre. “A clever and dynamic use of space was a key goal in the clients’ brief as the home lacked storage space. We also improved the circulation while enhancing the natural character of the property. Today, smart, integrated storage solutions are found throughout the flat: from the solid oak bed with storage incorporated for luggage, to custom millwork around the bed and sofa, which hides both unsightly radiators and snowboards,” the designers explain. In the kitchen, a pull-out pantry and breakfast shelving create a practical, easy-access space for food and appliances, while a multipurpose desk/island/console provides an ideal workspace for two, as well as serving as a sturdy, practical surface for unloading groceries and other items.

The apartment’s aesthetic was shaped in part by the client’s love for Duelle’s joinery designs from an earlier project, the A. Gallo boutique in Assisi, Italy. “Natural oil rubbed European oak was carefully selected and used to delineate different areas within the apartment,” the designers explain. In the kitchen, they used heavier lines and shadows, adding drama and emphasis to the matte green Brazilian quartzite countertop and backsplash. “To create a feeling of spaciousness, a common palette was used throughout the apartment. Each room features a unique color for its walls and ceilings, which gives a strong impact to otherwise small spaces. Pale green tones were used in the bathroom and kitchen/living area to create a feeling of spaciousness, while the bedroom is wrapped in a rich shade of peach. Custom oak cabinets were designed for each room, with a single slab of quartzite carefully divided and used in both the kitchen and bathroom,” Nardella and Law explain.

Traces of the area’s past are reflected in some elements of the interior, from the basket-weave pattern of the parquet floors to the tiles in the bathroom, inspired by ancient Roman tiles found in the neighborhood that date back to the days when Londinium was a remote outpost of the empire. Much attention was paid to the choice of vintage glass lighting fixtures, a nod to the long history of glassmaking here. With their previous experience as designers of luxury hotels and private residence in London, Duelle was a natural choice for Lisa and Wade’s pied-à-terre. The result is a compact and stylish apartment with the feel of a luxury nest where everything has its defined role, all contributing to the invitingly domestic feel of the home.
